Breeding adult (American).description: Herring Gulls are larger than Ring-billed Gulls with a bigger bill. Breeding and nonbreedng adults have pink legs, not yellow like Ring-billed Gulls. They also lack the Ring-billed Gull's black ring around the bill.

Second winter (American).description: Second winter Herring Gulls can be separated from immature Ring-billed Gulls by their larger size and bigger bill.

Juvenile (American).description: Juvenile Herring Gulls are best separated from juvenile Ring-billed gulls by size. Herring Gulls are larger with a bigger bill.

Breeding adult.description: California Gulls are larger than Ring-billed Gulls. Breeding and nonbreeding adults have a red spot on the lower bill and lack the namesake ring around the bill like Ring-billed Gulls. Also note dark eye on California, but pale on Ring-billed.

Second winter.description: Second winter California Gulls can be separated from first winter Ring-billed Gulls by their larger size and darker gray backs.

First winter.description: First winter Laughing Gulls have a gray neck and smudgy head unlike juvenile and first winter Ring-billed Gulls. They also have a longer drooping bill than Ring-billed Gulls.

Juvenile.description: Juvenile Laughing Gulls are more gray brown than the tan colored juvenile Ring-billed Gull. They also have thin eye crescents and a longer drooping bill.
